Now, I am an American, and, as an American, I was raised in a country that is a Federation of 50 United States, each State having its own identity, its own State Government, with it's own laws and it's own Executive Governor, Legislative Senate and Judicial Court, each State even has it's own State Military known as the State Gaurd, each with a Army Branch known as the National Guard, a Navel Branch known as the Coast Gaurd and an Air Force Branch known as the Air Gaurd. But all 50 states are United under a single US Federation, the US Federal Government centered in Washington DC. So I understand if you believe my American way of thinking gives me a bias for Federation between sovereign States, leading me to have that much more optimism for "The United Kingdoms of Europe" Or the UK of E. That said, the EU is most definitely worthwhile, and well, each of the United Nations of Europe do have their own identity, rich with history, customs, and traditions. They each have their own government with their own laws and government structure, I can most definitely assure all concerned that Federal Unity is possible and quite necessary for the Europeans, first the European Federation, the European Union is responsible for ensuring interconnection between the different European countries, which is a security wall preventing any future European war, and war is truly horrible. It was horrible in the days of melee weapons and it is all the worse today in the modern age of WMDs, as Sir Lancelot put it in that short story, "We have World Wars now, we number them to tell them apart. We fought our wars with swords, and with lance, now there are weapons that can fire a city in the blink of an eye, and poison the Earth for longer than you. Merlin has slept." The point being that we must prevent war any way possible, and the EU is a key to accomplishing that goal. Farther more the EU streamlines travel and collaboration between people of different European countries, leading to ever greater innovation, which leads to improvements in quality of life for all, from the Scientific, Technological and Industrial advances that come from that collaboration. The Unity of the EU also gives the European countries more leverage to push back at organizations that infringe on the rights of European citizens, one British parlorment member brought this up by discussing food safety laws in the US, stating how he couldn't believe hearing that US law allows for acceptable levels of contamination in our food supply, believing at first that Americans would never tolerate such contamination in our food supply, until he read it for himself from an American law book, the parlorment member stating on the British parlorment floor "If the food companies can push America around like that, what chance can we ever have if we leave the EU?" This makes the EU just as much a safe guard for European rights as it is a safe guard against European wars. So yes, the EU is more than worth it. Now that said, to address the challenges. American history has demonstrated time and again how Unity between states requires federal cohesion, that the federal government must set some basic ground rules which all member states need to adhere to. The US civil war, being just one particularly famous case in point. So just as the US federal government had to do and must continue to do it, the EU needs to set and enforce some constitutional ground rules for UE member states to adhere to. This will likely mean the EU will have to take swift and forceful action against any member states that refuse to comply with these ground rules, and that will likely prove unpopular especially among the citizens of the offending member state, but if push does come to shove, it will have to be done. We Americans sadly had to fight a war to abolish slavery in our own country, because the southern states refused to comply with Presidential orders and US Constitutional mandate to discontinue slavery, and chose instead to rebel against the Constitution's infringement on their "right to own slaves." Leading to the US civil war. Hopefully, the European citizens of any such rebelling European countries will be able to learn from that tragedy of US history and sufficiently wise up and promptly comply with the EU federal mandates before it comes to that. That all said some ground rules the EU will have to establish and enforce as needed include but may not be limited to the following 
1: European money 
Well the EU established the Euro as a continental currency for all European Union member countries to except as a common currency, the EU will likely have to mandate that all EU members adopt the Euro as their sole currency, so as to more strongly unite all member economies under this single monetary system. This will likely mean more than simply prohibiting national currencies as each member states will also have to adhere to the EU set standards of the Euro's rate of exchange and overall value of economic power. This will likely include the EU needing to set a single federal European minimum wage standard and will likely need to set EU federal taxes for any EU federal services. 
2: Standards for transparency 
As you said in your video the EU needs to be more transparent in what they do for the common European and how they do it, this will likely require EU information services, such as publication of EU government records for news media and the general European public to access, this will likely require an EU established information infrastructure including European federal public libraries which will require EU federal standards for general operations including architectural standards for accessibility and accommodation for Europeans with applicable ability differences. This standardization of information infrastructure will likely have to include an EU federal standard language for all European Union members so as to ensure sufficient bridging of language barriers between citizens of different member nations, with the EU likely going to need to mandate this single EU language as the sole language for all EU member nations ultimately abolishing all national languages in favor of the single EU Federal language. 
3: Utility infrastructure 
As the EU builds ever more collaboration and interconnection between the different member nations, any incapatabilities between different nations' infrastructure will become more and more of an issue. So, the EU is going to need to set EU federal standards for connections, utilities standards, system standards, and anything else that would affect the capatability of work interconnection. 
4: European immigration 
As a sovereign nation, the EU is a jurisdiction with defined sovereign dominion, which includes defined borders and citizenship. As such, the EU is going to have to establish and enforce those standards that are going to include standards for non European peoples entering the European Union sovereign domain and becoming citizens of the European Union. Including a European Union Federal standard for immigration entry and citizenship naturalization process. Including standards for the rights of the immigrants entering the EU member nations and how the member nations may treat the immigrants entering the EU's common federal domain. With the EU likely going to have to set a common standard of distribution of responsibilities among the member nations to ensure each member Nation carries their fair share of the challenges related to the entry and integration/assimilation of these new citizens.

comments.author: @kurzgesagt
comments.text:
Hey Everybody! So this video has a mistake and we remade it!  You can watch the corrected and updated Version here: https://youtu.be/uzkD5SeuwzM

What is the mistake? In a nutshell: It is not PHYSICALLY impossible to leave the Local Group as we said in this version. It is just extremely unlikely that we’ll ever do it, even for the standards of our videos.
BUT: If you have a lot of time and a fast spaceship you can still fly to a limited amount of galaxies – these galaxies will eventually get out of reach forever but until then, they are within reach. Although every second some of them escape us forever.

Ok, if this is so why did we keep the video up and not purge it when we deleted our addiction and refugee crisis videos? Well, it has to do with the nature and severity of the mistake: This mistake was much more straight forward then with the other two videos, so we did talk to a few astrophysicists to ask them what they thought and if we should take down the video. Their feedback was pretty clear, they thought it was still fine as the universe expansion things explained in the video are correct and they didn’t consider the local group thing as too major. This was actually a case of “good enough”.

Also, back when this original upload happened, Kurzgesagt was operating at pretty tight margins and just redoing a video was not easy for us. Back then the team was small and we were fighting to put new videos out. So we just swallowed the bitter pill and kept the video around.

But the video still bothered us, as far as we know this was the biggest unfixed mistake on the channel. Super frustrating, especially because the core idea of the video is so fascinating. The limit of our species. The actual limit. So yeah, we finally remade the video, sorry for taking this long, life got in the way.

The original video will stay up, you can compare the two if you want to see how far we have come in a few years in terms of production quality. All in all, we could only grow the channel and work on getting better because of direct support from you guys. So thank you for that. – Philipp

PS: If you want, check out our shop for some new posters about the universe posters and black hole plushies and stuff like that: kgs.link/shop​

metadata.title: What Happens AFTER Nuclear War?
metadata.description:
This video was made possible through a grant by Open Philanthropy.
Sources & further reading: https://sites.google.com/view/sources-nuclear-winter

Check out our biggest sale yet! Help support our birbs in moving to a bigger warehouse, 
and get a great deal for yourself on some kurzgesagt favorites: https://shop.kgs.link/Sale24 


A nuclear bomb is the most devastating explosion ever created. 
One bomb can end tens of thousands of lives immediately and 
hundreds of thousands through the radioactive aftermath. However, 
the worst part comes afterward: a nuclear winter that might kill billions, 
potentially leading to the complete collapse of our civilization.

In a nuclear winter, there are no winners – only starving losers.
How exactly does it work and what would it look like?

metadata.title: How Small Is An Atom? Spoiler: Very Small.
metadata.description:
Atoms are very weird. Wrapping your head around exactly how weird, is close to impossible – how can you describe something that is SO removed from humans experience? But then again, they kind of make up everything, so let us try anyways.

metadata.title: The Last Thing To Ever Happen In The Universe
metadata.description:
Get 50% off your first month of KiwiCo at https://www.kiwico.com/kurzgesagt with code KURZGESAGT.  
This video was sponsored by KiwiCo, thanks a lot for the support!

Sources & further reading:
https://sites.google.com/view/sources-sources-lastthing/

The universe today is happy and healthy, with exciting things going on – but at some point the night will turn dark. Everything that once was, will peacefully sleep forever. 
But what is the last thing that will ever happen? Let's travel to the end of the universe…

metadata.title: The Death Of Bees Explained – Parasites, Poison and Humans
metadata.description:
In 2015 the bees are still dying in masses. Which at first seems not very important until you realize that one third of all food humans consume would disappear with them. Millions could starve. The foes bees face are truly horrifying – some are a direct consequence of human greed. We need to help our small buzzing friends or we will face extremely unpleasant consequences.

Check out THE NOVA PROJECT: www.nova.org.au

metadata.title: The Fermi Paradox — Where Are All The Aliens? (1/2)
metadata.description:
The universe is unbelievably big – trillions of stars and even more planets. Soo… there just has to be life out there, right? But where is it? Why don’t we see any aliens? Where are they? And more importantly, what does this tell us about our own fate in this gigantic and scary universe?

comments.text: I know this sounds crazy but it feels like...propaganda. 😂

comments.author: @Fernandino-y8l
comments.text:
I still think the most obvious explanation is distance and rarity. I dont think life is so rare that we are alone, the evidence we have seen for our development doesnt point to that being the case as of yet. But I do think it is considerably rare. And even among planets with life on it, life intelligent enough to become advanced is rare. Look how many species exist now and have existed in the past on earth, and only 1 of them, Humans, were able to become the advanced civilization we are now (relative to the animal kingdom, at least). There could only be one planet in every similarly sized galaxy, or hell one per 10 galaxies, or even a hundred, that actually has life on it, and of those, perhaps only 1 in a thousand has intelligent enough life to become advanced. And then of those, its even less that have actually reached type 3, we havent even hit type 1 yet. So I imagine that these type 3 civilizations probably exist but are extremely far away from us, perhaps so far that the light carrying the evidence of their existence (and ours vice versa) hasnt reached us yet. And even if it had, would it even be possible for them to tell we are here? Would it even be possible for us to tell theyre there? We cant even figure out if there is and isnt other life within our solar system yet, if I remember correctly theres a space mission to search for life on one of mars moons happening in the near future. Let alone neighboring solar systems let alone our galaxy or the whole universe.

Advanced life IS out there, we are just too far apart to know about eachother. I think there have been and will always be filters in our past and future, thats the nature of survival, challenges always present themselves. But even in those instances of apocalypse, AI wouldnt have a logical reason to annihilate all life on earth like they would to eliminate humans, and full on nuclear war also wouldnt completely eliminate life, nor will climate change, even if all of those scenarios eliminate humans. Which means intelligent life would have a chance to reemerge after the recovery of the planet. (Plus, in an AI takeover, wouldnt those AI then go on to make their own civilization? The same paradoxical lack of evidence applies to that as well...)

comments.author: @y_fam_goeglyd
comments.text:
Back in the 1970s, I had measles & rubella badly. I still have facial scars from the measles. I had chicken pox, bronchitis and everything else except polio (thankfully I was vaccinated - or rather given it on a sugar cube!), mumps and smallpox. I cannot be vaccinated against smallpox (at least I couldn't when I was young, heaven only knows if the warnings have changed) because I had severe eczema as a baby. (It's not as severe now, thankfully!) It apparently could have had nasty side-effects including blindness. Fortunately, the _vast_ majority of people had the vaccine, so I never needed it. I can't tell them how grateful I am that they did that.

You can be damned sure that my four kids got every available vaccine, mostly to protect them, but also to protect those who couldn't. Don't be an anti-vax idiot. If you don't like the MMR schedule, your GP can work with you on it. But if your kid gets measles especially, you could be signing their death warrant, or that of a vulnerable neighbour or relative. If they survive, they may well go deaf and/or blind. I'm sure they wouldn't thank you for that.

comments.text: We have studied 20 million stars, and not one can support life as they are ALL too unstable, we are alone. The Sun is the only stable star. Also of the 4,300 solar system studies, not one looks like our solar system, able to support life. The Milky Way Galaxy is the only stable barred spiral galaxy. In other galaxies, there is no place for a rocky planet without deadly radiation or orbit interference. Earth’s vast and stable magnetic field is unique, most planets the magnetic field is short-lived or unstable. Earth’s magnetic field protects life from deadly radiation. The list can go on and on (rotation rate, astrosphere, right carbon dioxide, low carbon monoxide, one large moon, very low eccentricity). There are 5,759 confirmed exoplanets, not one looks like Earth or any of the planets in our solar system. Also needed for complex life are Solar System's belts. Only our system as solar system's belts. Most systems have not belts and a few have only one large belt. The belts give us near circular orbit. We have looked and we are alone.

On the one hand solving the deadliest diseases while also creating viruses more dangerous than nuclear bombs, able to devastate humanity. 

What is going on?

metadata.title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
metadata.description:
So what is the difference between you and a rock? This seems like an easy, even stupid question. But even the smartest people on earth have no idea where to draw the line between living and dead things. Which leads to mind-blowing implications. What is life after all? And is death really a thing? Lets look into it together

http://waitbutwhy.com/ has the follow up article up: http://bit.ly/1vJBzCU Have I mentionend yet that you should read it? Check them out, by far the best blog on the internet.

comments.author: @lukasturm5277
comments.text: I am late to the party and most are not even gonna see this comment - but here goes nothing: The real ˝problem˝  with the GMO's is not the GMO's themselves, but the companies that produce them. One of the most fundamental rights of any farmers is to store some of the seeds from their previous harvest to plant them next year. They can do that, of course, for free. In the case of GMO's, however, the owners of the GMO's (the companies that produce and sometimes patent them), do not allow the farmers to keep those seeds for free - the farmers are obliged to pay for them each and every year. In some cases very brutal lawsuits happened even just because some farmers didn't realize they have, e.g. 30% of GMO's in their seeds, which got there from some other source in the first place. So the farmers are suddenly caught in an never ending loop of having to pay for their seeds, for which they previously did not need to pay. Not to mention the attempts of certain companies (e.g. Monsanto) who tried to patent whole organisms and tried to demand exorbitant prices for them. And this my friends is the real problem of the GMO's, not their toxicity. I am somehow surprised that Kurzgesagt failed to mention this.

The big question with GMO’s is unintentional consequences and the limitations of our knowledge. The truth is we probably couldn’t feed everyone on the planet with our GMO’s. 

I think heavily processed foods are the real issue that often gets blamed on GMO’s. The more we can get away from dyes, pesticides, bleaching, and other chemical applications the better - GMO’s can actually help with this.

Not to mention gmo crops can be made to include more and new nutrients in food that wouldn’t otherwise contain them.

metadata.title: Tired of Doomscrolling?
metadata.description:
Being a human in the 21st century often feels frustrating. We are clearly at the high point of our species, while at the same time life is incredibly hard! We are divided, unable to solve our problems while creating new ones, destroying our world in the process. In many ways the vibe is that we live in dark times. But as Terry Pratchett said, we are the storytelling ape, we think in narratives and live in a network of stories that make up our world. So without minimizing the darkness, we want to add a story that we find helpful for dealing with the world. 

Sources & further reading:
https://sites.google.com/view/sources-visionforhumanity/

metadata.title: There Is Something Hiding Inside Earth
metadata.description:
Get 50% off your first month of a monthly club with code KURZGESAGT at https://www.kiwico.com/kurzgesagt
This video was sponsored by KiwiCo. Thanks a lot for the support!

Sources & further reading:
https://sites.google.com/view/sources-deep-biosphere/

We’ve found a new planet, home to octillions of the most extreme beings living in the most absurd and deadly hellscape. In absolute darkness, crushed by the weight of mountains, starved of oxygen, cooked alive, bathed in acid, salt or radiation. And yet, they live for thousands, perhaps millions of years! It turns out, this planet is not in space – it is inside the crust of Earth!
This is the deep biosphere and we basically learned that it exists yesterday. Its volume is at least twice as large as all the Earth’s oceans, home to more microbes than the rest of the entire planet.Their total biomass is more than 20 times greater than all humans, livestock, and animal wildlife. 
Let’s descend into this mad, deadly world where none of the rules we thought are mandatory for life apply.

comments.text: I believe your block universe theory is partially accurate; however, instead of a frozen future, I propose that all possibilities coexist simultaneously. For example, if you consider the scenario of missing a bus, the possibilities include: 1) arriving late for the bus, 2) successfully boarding the bus, 3) taking a taxi, or 4) receiving a ride from a friend. Each of these possibilities exists concurrently, and your actions ultimately determine which future will be your now

comments.author: @dontveter3372
comments.text: Bringing in quantum mechanics does not make sense.  If right now YOU don’t know if a radioactive atom is going to decay, someone, somewhere else in the universe, moving relative to you, already knows if it did.  So the block universe with it’s immutable past, present and future is what we have.  When people bring in quantum mechanics, they’re thinking from the standpoint of presentism, not the eternalism you get from the block universe.

metadata.title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
metadata.description:
Every second of your life you are under attack. Bacteria, viruses, spores and more living stuff wants to enter your body and use its resources for itself. The immune system is a powerful army of cells that fights like a T-Rex on speed and sacrifices itself for your survival. Without it you would die in no time. This sounds simple but the reality is complex, beautiful and just awesome. An animation of the immune system.

comments.author: @jwheeler9991
comments.text: We have no idea of previous population, neither are today's figures anything but a guess. We know it's ungrounded panic but we have people that wish us to fear everything. I believe most populations actually worked in equilibrium until codexing of laws. You can see this in the UK, and what changed with the Roman occupation. This caused the population to bloom when previously we kept population in check with our environment.  But thanks for expounding a few myths. We are creating equilibrium again. It's time to stop the fear and debunk these folk that seem to want to reduce the population to none
